text_a: Remember what she said in my last letter?
Goodwill helps people get off of public assistance
Sherry learned through our Future Works class that she could rise out of mire of welfare system and support her family
Coming to Goodwill was first step toward my becoming totally independent
I am now totally off of welfare
Goodwill prepares people for lifelong employment
Here's another story of success from what might seem like unlikely source: Goodwill's controller, Juli
Cornell found number of employment options that he never dreamed existed after worksite injury forced him out of his job at foundry
Dear,
After lifetime of trials, Donna not only earned her GED at Goodwill, she earned job here

I wanted to be there
I had my second chance to change my life
Your gift to Goodwill will help many people who want to tell their own stories of success

Your gift is wise investment in community
For every dollar donated to Goodwill in , we helped our graduates earn estimated

What kind of work does Goodwill do?
Goodwill finds jobs for people with mental and physical disabilities

After Maureen's job coach taugustht her how to do her job in restaurant, we helped Maureen step out of shadow sometimes cast over people with physical and mental disabilities and find fulfilling job smack dab in middle of society
Every time we help someone find solution to their employment barrier, positive effects radiate throughout our community:
The business community welcomes not only another worker, but consumer with increased purchasing power
Parents act as role models of selfsufficiency instead of dependency
Tax dollars that would have been spent on public assistance are saved
You and I know that solutions to difficult problems do not just happen

once his tears have subsided, he confirms what his classmates have already figured out: he just received job offer his first in years
Addressing meeting at neighborhood center, Goodwill staff member tells audience how Goodwill can help them find and keep jobs

In order to develop job skills, man with some serious disabilities begins working in Goodwill's industrial division

These people and their successes are real

Following are excerpts from findings of Senate Ethics Committee's report on Sen Robert G Torricelli's dealings with David Chang:

Your acceptance of television and stereo CD player upon payment from David Chang of amount you understood to be cost to Mr Chang, rather than fair marchket retail value, evidenced poor judgment, displayed lack of due regard for Senate rules and resulted in violation of Senate Gifts Rules and, consequently, violation of your public disclosure obligations under Senate rules
The Ethics Committee was unconvinced
troubled by incongruities, inconsistencies and conflicts, particularly concerning actions taken by you which were or could have been of potential benefit to Chang

Continuation of personal and official relationship with Mr Chang under circumstances where you knew that he was attempting to ingratiate himself, in part through pattern of attempts to provide you and those around you with gifts over period of several years when you and your Senate Office were taking official actions of benefit to Mr Chang contacting United States Government officials, writing letters to foreign government officials and involving Mr Chang of his representatives in situations where you were meeting with officials of foreign governments evidenced poor judgment

The committee has also considered that principal source of allegations against you is David Chang, witness whose credibility has been called into question by Department of Justice, United States district judge and his own conduct
In court documents, government noted that Chang could not be trusted
On May , , Mr Chang was convicted of attempting to corruptly persuade witness to give false testimony, conspiracy to violate federal election law and violations of federal election law

After evaluating extensive body of evidence before it and your testimony, committee is troubled by incongruities, inconsistencies and conflicts, particularly concerning actions taken by you which were or could have been of potential benefit to Mr Chang

Therefore, committee expresses its determination that your actions and failure to act led to violations of Senate rules and related statutes and created at least appearance of impropriety, and you are hereby severely admonished

Further, committee notes section c of Senate Gift Rule concerning anything which is paid for at marchket value or returned as well as your commitment to pay for any item which committee might conclude were in violation of rules, and has further concluded that you must pay Chang amount sufficient to bring total to fair marchket retail value of TV and CD player, as well as fair marchket retail value of earrings given to individuals at your home, with appropriate interest

The committee criticized Torricelli for maintaining personal and official relationship with Chang under circumstances where you knew that he was attempting to ingratiate himself, in part through pattern of attempts to provide you and those around you with gifts over period of several years

personal and official relationship with Chang under circumstances where you knew that he was attempting to ingratiate himself, in part through pattern of attempts to provide you and those around you with gifts over period of several years

The red harvester ant lives in hot, dry deserts, building its nests in light yellowy sand and foraging for seeds deposited by winds and rain

The ants forage for more than different varieties of seeds, many of which do not grow in desert Gordon, , where only few varieties of small shrubs, small herbaceous flowering plants and short grasses do grow Gordon,
Introduction
Motors
Antie's motors will allow it to move around and interact with its environment and fellow ants
There will be individually operated motors to drive side wheels in lieu of legs
simultaneously operated motors will open and close grippers, emulating grasping power of ant's mandibles
A third motor will lift and lower grippers, allowing Antie to raise and lower gripped items as ant would by raising and lowering its head
small sprayers will emit successful patroller and forager pheromones and cuticular hydrocarbons from appropriate sacs
Antie will not spray different pheromones depending on its task, on assumption that its time in sun will alter its hydrocarbons enough that its tasks will be recognizable to other ants
Other insects and creatures, including other species of ants, are present in desert, but red harvester ants seem to be relatively undisturbed by these animals Gordon,
Almost all motor output will be direct function of sensory input as indicated in following section
Antie will have hybrid software architecture: subsumption hierarchy will be responsible for switching between behaviors, but many subbehaviors will operate on schema basis
Pseudocode will approximate this architecture as closely as possible, and where appropriate, different subroutines running on schema basis will be marchked
Common Behaviors
A few subbehaviors will be necessary for more than behavior
The following global variables will be used throughout pseudocode, and are compiled here for ease of reference:
Background
Though fights sometimes do break out with other red harvester ants from different nests, intraspecies interactions tend not to be aggressive Gordon,
Because of this, I will ignore other ant species in design of Antie, and will not create fighting behavior

Common behaviors will include forward cruise and turning mechanism, procedures to determine orientation towards nest and distance from nest when outside, innest navigation, escape function for when objects are detected or bumped into, object identification and gripping, generic algorithm for pheromone plume and chemical trail following, and identification of other ants
Science fiction writers have been anticipating humanoid androids that could pass Turing Test for years
The Ant Robot
Ants of this species are of types: breeding ants queens and drones and sterile female workers
These behaviors will often be used in other subroutines running on schema basis, and when combined with forward cruise function, should cause robot to move at angle

In order to orient itself toward nest while navigating outside, Antie will need to determine which direction nest is in and rotate toward that heading, and also how far from nest it is at its current location

Antie will therefore have polarization function that will return compass direction toward which it should orient in order to return home to nest, and distance function that will return shortest direct distance
We may assume that this first function will return direction in degrees, positive or negative, and that second function will return distance in centimeters
Queens and drones will not be considered in this proposal, as their behaviors and design is much more specialized and would be applicable only during breeding season, which occurs but once per year

This void function will be called nestEnter , and will take in no inputs

For purposes of calls later in pseudocode, I will refer to these subroutines as trailFollow , findFood , and findMidden

The code will be similar to object identification subroutine and may look something like this:
Using these basic common behaviors, more complex behaviors may be coded
Red harvester ants do not retain task throughout their lifespan, but instead change their behaviors as is appropriate for colony Gordon,

Research has shown that red harvester ants switch tasks partially as function of age ex, Ingram, et al, and partially as function of interactions with other workers ex, Schafer et al, ; Gordon, ; Greene Gordon,
Younger ants work more inside nest, and older ants work more outside nest
As result, I will model main behaviors in order that they are to be engaged in

Midden work, which consists of moving dirt between inside of nest and outside, will occur first; patrolling, which involves shorter overall amount of time spent outside, will occur second; and foraging will be final behavior
Finally, I will discuss main method encoding task switching between these behaviors
The midden work behavior will be Antie's default initial behavior
It will be initiated in morning by sunrise, and will continue until outside temperature reaches oC, at which all red harvester ants must return to nest
As previously stated, midden worker must identify midden, grasp it, and carry it to surface, depositing it halfway down mound before returning to collect more midden
A program encoding this behavior might look like this:
These behaviors each present different puzzles to ant and to modeler, though there is some overlap, particularly with navigational problems
Nest patrolling will involve leaving nest, roaming around on nest mound for few minutes, and reentering nest
This behavior will be implemented in parts, with taskswitching algorithm based on age

Research shows that ants do change their behaviors based partly on their perceived life expectancy Moron, et al, , and that taskswitching is partly genetically controlled by switch in gene expression as individual ages Ingram, et al,
Harvester ants display preference to wander in familiar territory, though foragers and patrollers do sometimes wander into other nests' territories Gordon,

In case of midden work, Antie must be able to identify garbage, grasp it, carry it out of nest, and deposit it about halfway down mound before returning to repeat process ad infinitum or until stimulated to switch behaviors
To control for this behavior, Antie's explore subroutine will display preference for exploration in places where there is low gradient of nestmate pheromones
This model is reasonable because patrollers and foragers change their explored territory from day to day, even though they do retain some more commonly chosen paths Gordon,

Patrolling may be divided into distinct subbehaviors, nest patrolling and trail patrolling
Trail patrollers will go much further, until food sources are found, and will then orient towards nest and create trails for foragers to follow

An ant engaged in nest patrolling must exit nest at proper time in morning and wander about for bit on nest mound, presumably taking measurements of temperature and humidity in some way and making sure that it is safe for other ants to exit
A general site of food is all that patroller need find; foragers will dig through sand for food
Code for patrolling behavior might look like this note that part is on schema basis :
The integers nestpatrolage and trailpatrolage will represent ages at which it is appropriate to switch to these tasks

Perhaps level of degradation of nest patrollers' cuticular hydrocarbons after this short foray into sun and heat acts as indication of outside conditions to foragers, who may then, upon smelling returning patroller, be stimulated either to forage or to remain inactive inside nest

Andrew Russell to localize object through sand based on chemical plume
This will emulate digging that foragers must often do in order to locate seeds, and will enable Antie to accurately retrieve seeds for its host nest

An ant engaged in trail patrolling must exit nest, wander around searching for food sources, identify food upon discovery and return to nest to show foragers where food is
Because midden work behavior is Antie's initial default behavior, I will not address task switching to midden work

This is thought to be accomplished by deposition of chemical marchkers from gland on abdomen that patroller drags along ground on her return route to nest that foragers may then follow Gordon, ; Holldobler et al, , as cited in Webb,

Biomimetic robots have long been rich source of information for both biologists and robotics engineers, and complex robots that can switch tasks as situation demands and communicate information about current tasks could be useful for further studies of complex robot behaviors as well as for obvious practical applications of robot swarms, such as on battlefield and standard building maintenance

The Agent
Chassis
Antie will be implemented on tiny Road Warrior robotic system
Behaviors will be coded in Interactive C, for which some pseudocode is included
Sensors will include thermometer, photoreceptors, bump sensors, polarization compass, and series of chemical receptors
Antie be circular robot, no more than cm in diameter length of red harvester ant , with driving wheels and rear wheel for stabilization
A gripper will be located on front of robot consisting of elongated tongs
These sacs will be refilled at filling station each morning as Antie determines that they are getting depleted
Antie will likewise recharge at special station at night just inside nest entrance
For purposes of this proposal, I will assume that Antie has enough battery life to remain powered whole day
A rudimentary blueprint of Antie is attached

In attempt to mimic red harvester ant as closely as possible, these sensors include thermometer, photoreceptors, bump sensors and sonar, polarization compass, and series of chemical receptors on pair of stalks corresponding to antennae
On its front grippers, Antie will have tactile skin to sense pressure
The locations of rest of these sensors will depend on their function
The thermometer will be located on rear of robot to keep it out of way, and will detect and input to robot outside temperature in degrees Celsius
Harvester ants do not exit nest when outside temperature is above degrees Celsius Gordon, , and ability to use temperature gradient will enable innest navigation
Antie will also be equipped with photoreceptor located in middle of top of its chassis corresponding to ant's eyes

These will be useful for initiating patrolling behavior in morning and shutting off behaviors at night: patrollers first poke their heads out of nest shortly after sunrise and scuttle back in at night Gordon,

No robot has yet been constructed, however, that could pass undetected within colony of red harvester ants species Pogonomyrmex barbatus; nor has robot managed to pass undetected in society of insects while combining in its design several different behaviors and thresholds of stimulation required to switch between them
The bump sensors and sonar will form skirt around Antie to keep it from colliding with other objects
The sonar will correspond to ant's limited optical object detection ability, and bump sensors will allow robot to detect collisions
The polarization compass will consist of polarized light sensors placed at and degrees from center front of Antie, respectively, that will orient Antie towards desired polarization pattern

These sensors would correspond to cells in ants' eyes sensitive to polarized light, and research has shown that many insects, including ants, do navigate using path integration system synthesizing input from polarization compasses and from sort of odometer Labhart, et al,
This should be sufficient to return Antie to nest, given accuracy achieved by Lambrinos, et al and relatively short periods of time that harvester ants spend outside nest before returning

However, it reflects on greater level both desire of many Mayans to assimilate, as they still feel that is necessary for social mobility, and belief among general population that Mayans do not require septemberarate bill of rights as they are covered under general rights already in constitution Warren : ,
Illiteracy rates are in fact correlated with Mayan language itself: those who speak Spanish are more likely to be literate than those who speak Mayan alone England :

Nonetheless, in legislature passed law of national languages, which while reaffirming Spanish as official language, recognizes importance of indigenous languages as part of national identity and encourages their active promotion

Within panMayan movement, there remains desire to maintain linguistic diversity: some view reduction of their language to status of dialect devalues their unique identity and place in Mayan world; however, despite differences over standardization, panMayan movement itself is largely cohesive

An example is Tukanoans: while considered single ethnic group , they maintain distinct language groups and practice linguistic exogamy, in which members of language group must marchry into another Jackson :
Language further works to establish identity by encapsulating worldview marchkedly removed from that of dominant Western culture

Indigenous cosmology, or cosmovision , is difficult to translate into Romanticized languages; it maintains concept of culture, defined as form of behavior resulting from permanent harmonic relationship with Nature Gow and Rappaport : and view of history as cyclic that is often at odds with Western modes of thought
Conflict between cultures arise as cosmovision is rediscovered and developed, often by native shamans in tandem with indigenous leaders aided by outside researchers and nongovernmental organizations
The differences between Western and native perceptions then lead to conflict within revitalization movements themselves: question of embracing Western law and discourse is continually grappled with

Language plays complex and integral role in development and redefinition of identity, particularly when that identity has been oppressed and subsumed by dominant other for as long as that of indigenous peoples in Latin America has In particular I will examine divergent yet remarchkably parallel cases, that of Maya in Guatemala and Nasa and Guambiano peoples of Colombia

Customarchy law in Colombia contrasts with Western law as it maintains different perception of casual relationships: tying back to indigenous concept of harmony, crimes are viewed as imbalances in community's harmony and can often be traced back to those who did not perpetuate crime, but may have influenced accused to do so
When punishment often public and corporal in nature is carried out, group feels effects as whole
Shamans often sit with criminal as he fills his sentence, sharing in their ordeal
Rappaport Once punishments are completed, criminal is seen as rehabilitated, having fulfilled his duty to restore harmonic order, and is welcomed back into community Gow and Rappaport : , Rappaport :
Translation of law into native languages has proved to be difficult task, as Western ideas often have no parallel in indigenous cosmovision

The translation of Colombian constitution sparked development of neologisms, as goal of translators was not to provide direct translation of constitution, but to recapture its spirit in native, rather than Western discourse Gow and Rappaport :
This provides second interpretation of law distinct from that of Spanish Colombian culture, and in turn interpretation aligned with native ideology for cabildos to follow when governing Rappaport : ,
Translation fulfills another vital role, as it is employed in rediscovery of indigenous identity itself
Workshops and advocacy groups regularly work to translate native histories back into native forms of knowledge, distancing them from Western influences that have invaded over past centuries

The Guambiano history project charts native history as outward spiraling events which are both cyclic and parallel in nature; Mayan historians translate and document oral histories whose legacy is in danger of being forgotten Rappaport :
This attempt to regain identity via translation is indicative of intimate relationship between indigenous revitalization within modern context and native language use
Difficulties arise, however, as conflicts between traditional and modern and native languages and Spanish develop
Many native peoples in Colombia are monolingual Spanish speakers, raising question of practicality of indigenous language use

The authenticity of modern Nasa, who are often metropolitan Spanish speakers attempting to reconnect with their roots, is brought into question by traditional, who speak Nasa Yuwe and lead rural existence Rappaport

In Guatemala fact remains that Spanish is gateway to social mobility; years of conflict and refugee status have established desire to leave rural way of life for updated urban one, and those literate in Spanish have tools to do so

Illiteracy and poverty is associated with Maya; thus there is conflict between desire to recapture unique Mayan identity via language and need to improve living conditions, which most often occurs under Spanish influence
A further complication is necessity of establishing authentic Indianness , both in eyes of fellow indigenous peoples and outside Spanish culture

Politicians make of appearing in their native dress and speaking in their native language in assembly, even if they are more at home in business suit and speaking Spanish; indigenous identity has become calling card to extent that at times it appears to be caricature of itself
Efforts towards development, then, can not endanger traditional culture and values, for fear of losing cultural legitimacy Jackson :
There develops duality in native culture; for example, many Nasa children receive instruction in Nasa Yuwe yet converse in Spanish outside classroom
This intersection of language and indigenous identity poses challenges which have yet to be fully addressed

In Colombia, legal successes have often come about due to Colombian government's recognition of political viability of rhetoric of indigenous rights; by granting indigenous peoples judicial sovereignty they hope to win trust of people who view government as incapable of protecting them from ongoing civil strife, and by giving them blocks of land they hope that indigenous community will be able to keep out drug traffickers and guerrillas where government itself has not Jackson :
Regardless of ulterior motives behind their legal status, indigenous peoples in Colombia now possess rights to teach and govern in their own languages according to their own laws Jackson :
Conflicts arise due to internal differences and everpersist problem of defining indigenous identity and authenticity in pluralistic linguistic environment

but yes poor, sick dog was saying

The Exposition

As mentioned, first theme, beginning of which is reproduced in Example , contains head motives: first is tritonespanning ascent that appears in first measure, and second is iteration of interval cell , , that appears in second through third measures
Bart describes form of first movement as more or less regular sonata form
While presence of perfect fourths that was so prevalent in Introduction is clear in latter, former does not employ perfect fourth in its formation
Rather, this motive is smallscale representation of tonicdominant relationship of tritone partners, specifically F and B, that is basis for harmonic structure of this movement
Rhythmically, we have dissonance between melody, which follows written meter, and accompanying chords in bassoons, horns and lower strings
Example reproduces chords, and Example rewrites them in meter that is more consistent with their rhythmic pattern
This is in strict metric dissonance with triple meter of melody with its own hiccups occurring in written measures

While that does not seem to be meaningful assertion, it is perfectly accurate: movement is in sonata form, but there is introduction that does not relate thematically to any other parts of movement not unheard of in Mozart sonatas , and recapitulation presents themes of exposition in reverse order
We have already mentioned that first theme group is in F, this is made clear from onset, both in melodic line and by F minor triad that occurs on downbeat of measure
While material occasionally departs from this F in measures , these departures are all subordinate to prolonged F
E is tonal center for measures , although it does not appear as strong bass note until measure
Measures contain mostly chromatic descent from C to E , where E is anticipated throughout as goal tone for bass
Immediately following arrival of E in bass, C D is established as tonal center for final transition to second theme
The trombone motive in measures , shown in Example , is subject of fugato section in part of development, although its importance is downplayed here
This motive also contains intervallic cell of second head motive of first theme in form of G C BE with addition of some passing tones , in addition to consisting largely of motion by perfect fourths
While strong VI motion from measures does carry tonal implication of dominanttonic, such cadential bass motion does not imply anything about structural function in this context

The passage from measures is centered on E and pentatonic set from opening of exposition is transposed down whole step , but its mere presence as local tonic does not signify any sort of dominant function
Rather, we can consider this occurrence of E as middlegroundlevel wholetone descent that foreshadows structural descent to E at measure that is represented in Example
In measures , bass descends FE D C, which might seem to support C's functioning as structural dominant
However, as previously mentioned, C acts as fake dominant that in measures actually functions as upper neighbor to B, true dominant
The descent in measures in fact participates in farce by projecting descent ending on C, which makes eventual reinterpretation of C and descent to B stronger
The second theme is tranquil and harmonically simple, which is in stark contrast to first theme
B dominates as tonal center from measures with little or no harmonic motion away from it
The backwards recapitulation is technique that Bart employs frequently because of formal symmetry it creates
Measures are in E , with bass notes in harp, and measures are in D
A intervenes between E and D in measure , another instance of wholetone being filled in by fourth
The return to B in measure is also filledin in this way by F in measures
Paul Wilson points out that i n substituting for F within analogous structure, B receives confirmation at this as crucial interior center of movement
i n substituting for F within analogous structure, B receives confirmation at this as crucial interior center of movement
In our terminology, this is at which B is unequivocally established as structural dominant
The Development
As mentioned, development is divided into subsections

In Example , entire development section is represented by exactly pitches, and indeed each subsection is associated with of these pitches as its tonal center, none of these pitches is involved in structural wholetone descent

As Paul Wilson states, development is, for Bart's music, developmental in relatively conventional way ; themes from exposition are expanded and modified, and tonalities other than those expected arise
is, for Bart's music, developmental in relatively conventional way
For example, fifth string quartet
The only slight abnormality, though it is certainly not unheard of even in classicalperiod sonata movements, is emergence of new theme in second section of development
Although Wilson claims that this theme is based on transformation in rhythm and contour of second headmotive of firsttheme ,
Before beginning analysis of any piece by Bla Bart, must first decemberide to what degree tonal analysis will be used
Also see Bart's comments on that Bart,
there is no intervallic relationship between motives, and it is not clear what elements of motive remain when rhythm, contour and interval content are changed
Furthermore, this section, being middle section of movement, upholds formal symmetry if interpreted as its own theme
The first section of development, measures , begins with big Dminor chord which immediately establishes D as tonal center for section
Although it moves to E minor in measure , it returns to D minor in measure , which suggests that E is upper neighbor prolonging D
Example shows diagram of form of movement; symmetry is apparent within sections following introduction
The passage beginning at measure , shown in Example , can be considered to be theme of this section, and is development of second head motive of first theme
This motive undergoes inversion and extension throughout section
This section is reproduced as Example
The arrival at C was foreshadowed by first measures of development Example , which are almost direct transposition of head motives of first theme to C
Because of its emphasis here in development section and its position as leading to B in second theme group, we could conceive of C as subdominant in this movement

As example shows, development section is divided into subsections; first and third subsections draw their thematic material from first theme group, and second subsection involves new material not drawn from exposition

As tempting as this interpretation may be, this observation is relegated to notes section because it constitutes horrible abuse of terminology, there is only so far that such tonal analogies can go before they begin to hide any true analytical insight behind misused terms
The tonal center B is established immediately in measures by strong VI chord progression Example
As previously mentioned, fugato motive incorporates motion by perfect fourths found in Introduction as well as intervallic cell found in second head motive of first theme
The resultant set is pentatonic set FB E A D ; entire passage shown in Example remains within this set
The second instance of fugato section, not reproduced in its entirety but based on subject in Example , is exact pitch inversion transposed to begin on C
The inversion blends seamlessly back into original subject in measure

The following section measures especially brings out quartal harmonies within pentatonic set, so much so that B is obscured as tonal center which allows A to emerge as goal tone of this section, only to be immediately reinterpreted as leading tone to A that begins recapitulation
Hence, on either side of middle section of development we have alternation FTGSTGFTG which makes overall form, with exception of Introduction, symmetric
The Recapitulation
The recapitulation, as we have seen, presents themes in reverse order
The second theme is initially presented in A, as part of wholetone descent, and proceeds directly to G, where it is restated slightly modified
It is worth pointing out that arrival on G at measure is led into by D, which constitutes another filling in of wholestep by intervening fourth
The A in measure might initially seem to be new tonal area, but it leads to D in measure , which constitutes V chord still applied to G
Rather than resolve this D back to G, however, Bart shifts briefly to F in measure and leads to E in measure

E and F are both active throughout entire transition from second theme back to first theme measures which brings out their functions as upper and lower chromatic neighbors to F, which returns triumphantly in measure with muchanticipated recapitulation of first theme
The return of first theme is certainly immediately recognized as such; however, there are some important differences
Firstly, its initial appearance in exposition had minor flare to it; first chord in Example is Fminor triad, and first notes of Example ascend Fminor scale
Paul Wilson also discusses inherent symmetry of movement, although his interpretation is somewhat different

In addition to mode shift, we notice that metric dissonance shown in Examples and no longer appears notice how regular rhythm of accompanying figure is in Example and also that written meter no longer changes
In other words, piece, in becoming more regular, is beginning to drive towards finish, because of formal structure, recapitulation of first theme also serves as closing section of movement
Indeed, this section has feel of Coda to it, it is much shorter than any other major section or subsection, and tonic harmony is active throughout
See Wilson,
Bart is of many earlytwentieth century composers whose music fits entirely in gray area between tonality and atonality

While we know from his writings that he often composed with tonal centers and relationships in mind, and that he regularly applied tonal structures and forms to his compositions, by merely glancing at any of his pieces we can see that tonality as it is understood in common practice period is not at work

Thanks largely to work of tonal theorists such as Heinrich Schenker and others, we have detailed system for analyzing tonal music, their system, however, is virtually useless in analyzing music that falls entirely on atonal side of spectrum
But if we apply it to music such as Bart's that is in middle area, we can come up with some enlightening and perhaps unexpected results
To do so was goal of this analysis of first movement of Concerto for Orchestra

By applying our tonal system to music that slips outside of tonal realm, we not only find elements of tonality that do remain, but we also pinpoint exactly when and how this music breaks from previous conventions
It is not disputed that Bart's music has great expressive power, perhaps now we can understand why
References
Bart's music, although it is often difficult to call completely tonal, never entirely sheds itself of tonal elements and structure

When we say in F, we do not imply F major or minor, for that matter , majorminor tonal system in general does not apply to this piece, but rather that pitchclass F is tonal center of movement, and acts analogously to tonic in Mozartian sonata movement
Tonal Structure and Form in Bart's Concerto for Orchestra I
Using this interpretation, we can map out local tonics tonal centers used throughout movement, as shown in Example
In this example, barlines divide formal sections of piece Introduction Exposition Development Recapitulation , so we can immediately see that tonic F is not established until exposition begins
This remains true even with of his last compositions, Concerto for Orchestra, written years before his death in
See Bart,

In this particular movement, Bart feigns moving to tonal dominant, C, for second theme before reinterpreting C as chromatic passing tone between D and B, this and other subtleties shown in Example will be explained in detail in later sections

The graph in Example will serve as of departure for subsequent analysis; while we will periodically refer back to some of its specific elements, it should be understood that even when not explicitly referenced, this graph serves as explanatory goal of this paper
The Introduction
As Paul Wilson points out, title Introduzione given to movement as whole seems to apply only to first measures
The discussion that follows analyzes first movement of Concerto, focusing on tonal structures at play throughout movement
To begin with, opening motive in celli and basses, shown in Example , outlines pentatonic set and strongly presents C as tonal center
Indeed, this set can be seen more as byproduct of stacked perfect fourths than generative element itself
Furthermore, following instances of this opening motive, shown in Examples and , remove any doubt as to motivic importance of perfect fourth, and in turn diminish importance of pentatonic set
Example transitions from C to F , and adds pitchclass E to pentatonic set of Example , creating set of stacked fourths
Each note is either approached or left or both by fourth, and structural motion is from F to D
The overall motion in first measures is C to D , through F ; these are represented enharmonically in Example as D , E and G
As previously mentioned, this motion constitutes initial ascent to what will eventually be wholetone descent from F to F
So prevailing structural motion of movement as whole is descending whole step and prevailing melodic motion is usually ascending perfect fourth
We can connect by noting that descending whole step consists of ascending fourths; indeed, structural wholetone descent is often filled in with intervening fourth
This motion is exemplified in Example in second theme group mm
We will also examine to what degree tonal reading of this movement is limited in its analytical potential in attempt to pinpoint exactly where Bart strays from commonpractice compositional techniques
, and as we will see, it occurs in other places, though not relevant enough to background structure to be represented in Example

Each time motion in Examples through breaks from chains of fourths, same sequence of intervals occurs: descending perfect fourths septemberarated by ascending major second , , ; each instance of this intervallic cell is bracketed in examples
This sequence of intervals is inversion of those found in second head motive of first theme of exposition, shown in measures of Example

So although there is no thematic relation between Introduction and main sections of movement, within first measures we can already see structural, harmonic and motivic elements that apply to movement as whole
The section from measures is centered on E; upon return of D , enharmonically respelled as E , in measure , we see that E acts as its upperneighbor

This relationship is somewhat obscured by measures however; while there is no clear tonal center for this section, G appears in outer voices in measure , although harmonic material is reminiscent of C minor
The concluding motive of this section in violins bracketed sections of Example , as well as bass motive of measure ff
Example , are related to first head motive of first theme, which is shown in first measure of Example
All of these motives span tritone, which as mentioned is dominant relationship in this movement
Because of this it is possible to take up any given colors and make them harmonize
Why in world filled with color do we feel need to purge it from our space?
The white of walls intensifies color of what is set before them
It stabilizes and controls forms because it brings to light contours of space

In white painted room clarity of spatial sensation and disposition was surest and most convincing, all details of form and color of furnishings could be developed undisturbed in front of this background In this form was discovered which was completely convincing in its simplicity and which could be seen as of essential formulas for wall treatment in closed spaces
In th century it became fashionable for bourgeois women to dress in white, while men dressed in black Wigley
These distinctions proved certain rational order, only attained by those able to afford of it
White walls, white clothing, they both require much more maintenance than something colored where stain can merely hide away among other colors
Crisp whiteness on other hand expresses sort of luxury, and leisure

White clothing proved that someone was of level of society in which they were not forced to work, for clothing would immediately become soiled if not and thus reason why women who were ones to stay at home dressed in all white, while men who were ones to go out and work wore black, for black did in fact hide stains

The same goes with white walls, in their impeccability it proved to whoever, that owner could afford to not live actually live in this space, or could afford more simply for upkeep and constant fresh coats of paint
Both as well were signs of modern age man had reached
Pure white was de rigueur, partly because of its exciting novemberelty, partly because it emphasized smoothly mechanical texture, and pointed contrast between it and surrounding nature
The use of white was proof that man had conquered nature
Ever since dawn of man, human society has evolved in ways which attempt to ultimately control nature
The use of white and black in dress and architecture also became way of distinguishing oneself from vulgar, normal, lower classes
Furthermore, with advent of industrialization invention of new synthetic dyes meant that color in dress became democratized for all classes
Now, anyone could afford to wear colorful clothing and masses began to dress themselves in what once would have been inconceivable to them
Seeing as color is something of natural world, age old and archaic, washing it away from our lives is ultimate form of rising above physical world
This simplicity of dress was seen as marchk of modern man
Other major technologies during age of industrialization also had effect on this preference for black and white

Photography took over as means of portraiture for bourgeois and upper class and despite fact that it was possible to color photographs, for most part they were left in black and white because it was seen as more natural
This world was viewed as orderly and relatively uniform, world in black and white

This led to idea of writing rationality production that confined images, especially images in color, to emerging field of art , which was understood as essential activity but that was essentially unproductive, while it assigned to and orderly world of printed paper role of daily guide to existence
Intelligent beings have language represented by articulate sounds; organized beings, like all animals and vegetables, express themselves by cries or forms, contour or carriage
Black and white became symbol for superiority of man's intellect and technology

This then translated down into world of fashion, as seen with distinction between black and white clothing, as well as art, namely photography but also film and as discussed before architecture and gallery space
Seeing as since time of Aristotle, form was valued over that of color, arts which did not require color to be enjoyed were perceived to be that of higher form
Kitsch is product of industrial revolution which urbanized masses of Western Europe and America and established what is called universal literacy
In order to meet demand of mass marchkets cheap and bright things of little use were made to attract attention of consumers
Kitsch made cheap what once was truly cultural by way it reproduced it d infinitum
Kitsch is vicarious experience and faked sensations
Kitsch changes according to style, but remains always same
Kitsch pretends to demand nothing of its customers except their money not even their time
With advent of kitsch came great need for distinction between higher and lower artforms
Avant guard at time was considered to be true art, while this kitsch was simply pure imitation
Inorganic nature has only language of color

Thus said, this along with influence of black and white print perhaps was cause for belief that which was black and white was deemed serious, high art, while that which was colorful was mere rubbish and imitation for lower classes
Of course during early stages of color film and photography, quality was so poor that it gave cheap look, whereas black and white film really allowed to see light and shadows in images
For play of light and form was key in demonstrating true art form

It is by color alone that certain stone tells us it is sapphire or emerald color, then, is peculiar characteristic of lower forms of nature, while drawing becomes medium of expression, more and more dominant, higher we rise in scale of being
That was what made up essence of image, not artificial, or superficial filling in of form with color
Color was thought to distract viewer from soul of image
These beliefs have changed since color technology as tweeked to of being almost better than reality
Still though black and white is seen as something of more sober tradition
These non colors allow for appreciation of color
When something is black and white, it allows mind to fill in and imagine for itself amazing colors that must exist beyond screen
Many actually complained with invention of color in movies that this stunted mind since was forced to look at garish colors placed before them
It is for this reason that ultimately use of black and white is seen as more of intellectual process
Whether it mean going beyond mind or simply purity of non color, use of black and white has been debated over for last years

Now we have entered era where we are seeing once again more color, but perhaps it is human instinct, to want to surpass and rebel against generations before, so possibly we shall return to state of non color veneration
Thus is ebb and flow of life
The world is made up of myriad of colors color gives distinction to our life, it gives flavor and meaning
In Far East, reaching state of colorlessness is associated with highest state of spiritual being, state of Zen
What is typical of this sort of ascetism is art of expressing as much as possible using minimum as ideal
This is apparent through Japanese haiku as well as art of ink painting in both China and Japan
For them, reaching greatest depths of spirituality demanded expression in its most minimal form
This reduction of color and expression proved purity artist had reached within himself, it was means of reducing down to essence of thing
In Elimination of color in Far East, Izutsu explains though how this ultimate state of minimalism can only be reached through appreciation and fine knowledge of color

This artistic acestism, i e, suppression of externals and reduction of all colors to black and white, manifests its real aesthetic function only against background of highly refined sensibility for colors and their subtle hues
What would our lives be without color?
For black and white can only be seen as distinguishing against background of color and for this very reason can assert that both black and white are colors in themselves as noncolors
It is through absence of color that brings to mind colors that are no longer present
It is up to mind to fill in blank space
Without color could not appreciate purity of black and white space
That is to say, under total absence of color, there is vague reminiscence of all colors that have been killed
Black and white are consummation of all colors into one
Black is life; it is infinite possibility of expression and development Black here is not sheer black
For in it is negation of all colors, all colors are positively affirmed
It is through these means that finds essence in thing
In Western society, this purging of color began with rejection of ideals of generations past

I'm not to make New Year's resolutions
They suggested that what you believe about selfcontrol affects goals you set and achieve PDF
In paper, selfcontrol is used to mean sense of willpower
selfcontrol

Mukhopadhyay Venkatarmani discuss various lay theories of selfcontrol, noting that amount of selfcontrol person has can be seen as either inherently limited or unlimited resource, and that this resource can be seen either as malleable or as fixed amount of selfcontrol person has can change over time, or not

I mean, sure, I could take my pick of popular New Year's resolutions; I could decemberide, on first day of new year, that this year, I'll start exercising more and eating better, or that I'll spend more time with my family and friends, or that I'll learn new skill
An important premise to note here is idea that probability of choosing goal or making resolution increases if person thinks that goal can be attained
So if you think you will be able to achieve goal, you are more likely to set it
Combine this with theories of selfcontrol, and in general, if you believe you have unlimited stores of selfcontrol, you will set larger number of goals
Mukhopadhyay Venkatarmani also discuss selfefficacy: belief in one's capabilities, perceived ability to carry out desired action
Selfcontrol, Selfefficacy, and New Year's Resolutions Unresolved
The studies
In first study, participants all college students each read of passages presenting lay theories of selfcontrol
Each passage contained paragraphs; first discussed selfcontrol either as limited or as unlimited, and second discussed selfcontrol as either malleable or fixed
The participants then answered questions about their belief in each of theories presented, followed by second questionnaire to assess motivation, in which they listed all their current goals

The experimenters had some concerns about participants' natural beliefs in relation to passages they read, however, so in study two, order of measures lay theories and motivationgoal listing was varied

Data from new participants revealed that, as hypothesized, if motivation goals questionnaire were assessed first, then among people who believed selfcontrol is malleable, those who also believed selfcontrol to be unlimited vs
limited set more goals
When lay theories were assessed first, this result reversed
The people who believed that selfcontrol is fixed were unaffected by order
The third study moved on to examine goal achievement, adding measure to look at selfefficacy
The study had sessions, in November then February

In first session, participants read passages about lay theories much like in study one, but with longer passages to strengthen manipulation , listed resolutions they were planning on making at New Years, rated how disappointed they would be if they failed to keep their resolutions, and filled out individual difference measures which included selfefficacy scale
And if I chose to make resolutions, I'd be far from alone survey on Dorthy com found that of adults polled had made resolutions at some though only managed to keep them
Only participants successfully returned for second session, during which they indicated how much success they had had at keeping their resolutions
What does this mean for your resolutions?
The resolutions made by participants across all conditions were qualitatively similar take look at any list of popular New Year's resolutions, and you will see majority of goals

As shown in first studies, more goals were set by people who believe selfcontrol is unlimited and malleable than by any other people that is, if you expect more success, you may increase difficulty and number of tasks that you set for yourself
Selfefficacy did not have significant effect on goalsetting
As far as success goes, only interaction between lay theory and selfefficacy was significant
If participants believed in limited selfcontrol and were low in selfefficacy, they tended to give up more often, failing to achieve their goals

But in general, lay theories about selfcontrol can determine how much success you will expect and thus, how many goals you will set , and selfefficacy beliefs can determine how much success you will actually have
References
Mukhopadhyay, A Johar, G V
Where There Is Will, Is There Way?
Effects of Lay Theories of SelfControl on Setting and Keeping Resolutions
Journal of Consumer Research, , PDF
Making resolutions: It's about selfcontrol

The question Anirban Mukhopadhyay of Hong Kong University and Gita Venkatarmani Johar of Graduate School of Business at Columbia University asked is this: What determines how many goals person will set, and how successful person will be at achieving those goals?
They performed few studies in to look at relationship between selfcontrol, goal setting, and goal achievement

I was having serious cash flow issues back then and had payments to make, so I said, yes, but my patience was running out
It was dark as we left
When he killed headlights there was no light but moonlight and stars on light dusting of snow
A low, black hill blocked sky right in front of us
We spent next hour stomping around hill while he said things like, it was right here
My patience was long gone, and I was back in car to warming up when Acres tapped on window and told me he had found whatever he was looking for
We trudged back up hill and he led me to little patch of ground with stick poking up from it
It looked like bamboo walking stick
This is it, he leaned down and motioned for me to look at something on ground
See how lines form pattern in journal, same as moai
So you drew this? I asked vaguely, slow to catch on
So you drew this?
He looked hurt and rapped on ground with his finger
It's stone
Ancient
For first time he looked cold and stiff in his tourist gear, making me glad I was in suit
Here stand beside me, he said
I'm not sure if I can take you with me so I need to show you device
I expected him to pull out gadget with blinking lights and was wondering which way to duck
OK, watch and remember this
I'm going to do it in parts, last part first so it will not take effect
Stunned I watched as he made several ridiculous passes with his hands paused and nodded then did sort of sign language stutter of some sort
I learned this from skull shard rongorongo, they are not all writing language
Some are just memory device
Mnemonic
Yes
There's long history of Polynesian gesture and dance language
He smiled and I could see his teeth in moonlight
His hands were thin and huge knuckled with obvious callouses
I did not have much trouble duplicating his hand waving even though I had not paid much attention
I even swapped parts as he had asked
I thought he was surprised at my dexterity when his jaw dropped, but he shouted, No! just before everything changed
I was standing on perfectly flat square of dark stone
For as far as I could see by weak, gray light stone stepped up and down making little hills and terraces and platforms
I seemed to be somewhere in middle there was as much above as below
So, mining business is treating you pretty good, huh Charles?
The sky was dull and featureless and overcast
The air smelled bad in some way I can not describe, and at my feet I could see same design from little journal and mound carved into rock
I was in shock

Thus originated Las Vegas's reputation as adult theme park
The areas surrounding springs were desert oases: sprawling collections of grasses, trees, and wildlife
Additional catalysts for valley's growth came from World War II

Both Las Vegas Aerial Gunnery School which became Nellis Air Force Base and Nevada Test Site in north, and Basic Magnesium in nearby town of Henderson, arrived in early s as result of America's war effort
By , population had grown to almost , , with workers and airmen moving in at rapid pace
But this was not yet Las Vegas of folklore
During this period, East Coast Syndicate member Benjamin Bugsy Siegel earned foothold as local casino operator
Many springs lay in areas that would eventually become center of modern Las Vegas metropolis
But Mafia bosses who financed operation were displeased with its performance; Siegel was murdered in summer of
Despite its initial failings, Siegel's Flamingo survived him, as did mob infiltration of casinos
Freely flowing comps complimentary food, drink, and entertainment were order of day, with mob bosses content to provide environment of pleasurable excess as long as cash kept rolling in
While mob was running casinos, promoters were busily selling Las Vegas as glamorous Hollywood in desert
Many of them did
Frank Sinatra, Wayne Newton, and Louis Prima each arrived with mediocre status and suddenly found themselves with names as big as marchquees on which they were written
For about years, Archaics thrived in culture that included many signs of early civilization
The Rat Pack, originally Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr, Peter Lawford, and Joey Bishop, all in town to film Ocean's , landed at Sands in January for legendary stay
Other Hollywood stars came as well, simply because Las Vegas was place to be
As result, more casinos emerged along Strip

The Thunderbird, Desert Inn, Sahara, Sands, and Riviera hotels were erected during this period, luring curious clientele drawn by tales of allnight partying, exclusive entertainment, and cheap accommodations
There was no longer any question: when you wanted some unbridled adult fun, Las Vegas was place to be
New Legitimacy
Organized crime was soon to have formidable adversary in its bid to control Las Vegas, corporate cash
Signs of even more advancement appeared halfway through first millennium d, when Anasazi Indians inhabited valley
That would change dramatically with arrival of billionaire Howard Hughes
A legitimate businessman, Hughes was nonetheless eccentric and dramatic, style suited to Las Vegas ethos
True to myth, reclusive Hughes immediately cloistered himself in Desert Inn's penthouse
Thus began Hughes' legendary Las Vegas buying spree
When it was over, Hughes owned casinos, airport, and airline, along with numerous plots of land stretching from Strip to mountains
Hughes' actions would have beneficial repercussions, both immediate and lasting

Because of new legitimacy Las Vegas acquired from Hughes' investments, established companies such as Hilton Hotels bought into gaming business, and their influence helped draw line in desert sand between legitimate operations and mob casinos, where illegal skimming of profits was rampant
Las Vegas with Vision
As corporations moved in and mob was slowly pushed out, new Las Vegas emerged
Far more progressive than Archaics, Anasazi utilized such formal agricultural techniques as irrigation to assist their harvest
The legitimization of gambling led to its increased legalization across US
Casino operators had to reassess nature of their business
The first to really do so was Steve Wynn, Las Vegas resident and owner of Golden Nugget
In mids, Wynn began plans to reinvigorate Las Vegas with new resort
He bought several Strip properties, Silver Slipper and Castaways among them, and demolished them to make way for new kind of resort, Mirage, which became instant success
Wynn's casinos have also set new standards
They can no longer be just box filled with gaming tables, restaurants, and showroom
Excalibur, MGM Grand, Luxor, and New YorkNew York all followed Mirage's lead during s, offering themed environments and attractions for families
As evidence of everfaster nature of city, by middle of s new approach showed signs of backlash, with many visitors criticizing mediocrity of Las Vegas experience
This permitted Anasazi to achieve benchmarchk of advanced society, ability to live in permanent shelters yearround without need to follow wildlife
The latest approach is perhaps best of postmob era: comprehensive resort
New resorts offer attractions and amenities modeled after those available in top resort cities worldwide, including luxurious spas, signature restaurants, and exclusive boutiques
Additionally, handful of resorts, such as SouthSeas themed Mandalay Bay, Mirage, and new Seasons, are now catering exclusively to luxury travel marchket
The crme de la crme of Las Vegas deluxe is Steve Wynn's Bellagio
Perhaps more important, such highend accommodations raise standards of expectations back to mythology of Rat Pack era
As it changed from mob gam bling town to corporate gaming venue, population of Las Vegas skyrocketed
With its new look and new aim, prospects are good despite warnings
Mysteriously, Anasazi vanished from valley around d , leaving it to be repopulated by Southern Paiutes, another huntergatherer tribe
Inevitably, some people will get burned in process, but others will rise triumphantly from fray to even greater successes
And that, more than anything, is constant that characterizes past, present, and future of Las Vegas
Unable to replicate agricultural techniques of Anasazi, Paiutes were destined to seminomadic lifestyle until European settlers arrived, changing nature of existence in valley forever
During this period, indigenous people lived in caves, hunting mammals that gathered at shoreline
From Mailmen to Mormons
In early nineteenth century, America's western territories were still largely unexplored
For years, Las Vegas was used as Spanish Trail waystation
A Brief History
In , American explorer John C Fremont parked his horses at Big Springs, and his report to government resulted in mail route leading past spot on its way to California
This put Las Vegas on map and was of crucial turning points of its history
In , Mormon leader Brigham Young responded to promising reports of Las Vegas by sending missionary settlers to valley; they eventually built fort not far from today's Downtown
Surrounded by acres of farmland hewn from hard desert, adobe fort became focal for development of Las Vegas for next years
The landscape of valley changed dramatically over next centuries
The missionaries struggled valiantly against dictates of desert, trying simultaneously to survive harshness of their circumstances and spread Mormon faith
Additional pressures from arriving miners pushed missionaries' plight beyond recovery
Their supplies scarce, their harvest meager, and their spirit broken, they abandoned fort in
opportunist who stayed was Octavius Decatur Gass

Bestowed with plenty of invaluable pioneer spirit that characterizes Las Vegas to this day, Gass redirected his life by picking up where Mormons left off, at least when it came to ranching and farming
The glaciers feeding lake melted away and lake evaporated
Gass took over abandoned Mormon fort and acres hectares surrounding it, dubbing it Las Vegas Ranch
His determination had other results as well: Gass was named justice of peace and territorial legislator
Despite his ambition, Gass' success was shortlived
In late s, he defaulted on loan from rancher Archibald Stewart, so Stewart took Las Vegas Ranch for his own
Fossils tell obscure story of man's slow and sporadic development
Early Habitation
What happened next would marchk end of successful Las Vegas Ranch and beginning of era of subdivision seen across almost all of Western America to this day
Of Tracks and Tracts
At turn of th century Los Angeles and Salt Lake City were among burgeoning metropolises of new American West
Though cities remained unlinked by rail, this was about to change quickly
When it did, Las Vegas Valley which at time had nonnative population of less than would change as well
Around b c, native Archaic Indians began to develop lasting hunting and gathering culture
In , officials of San Pedro, Los Angeles, and Salt Lake Railroad arrived in Las Vegas, eager to secure rightofway for their Los Angeles Salt Lake connection
Las Vegas would serve as major stopover for crew rest and train repair
For all this, railroad needed land
As mapped, track traveled directly through Helen Stewart's Las Vegas Ranch
Stewart sold percent of her ranch to railroad
In early , route between Los Angeles and Salt Lake City was completed, and train tracks bore right down center of Las Vegas Valley
On May , railroad held land sale, momentous step in Las Vegas history
Standing at depot at Main and Fremont streets, railroad officials auctioned lots they had subdivided from square blocks of desert scrub
By this time, valley was in much same geographic state as it exists in today, with exception, presence of artesian springs that bubbled to surface in several areas
Las Vegas was no longer small pioneer settlement
With rail service in place and blocks of private property, it was ready to become real town
Businesses sprang up overnight, and wooden houses were erected to replace tent city in which many of early settlers had lived
year after auction, population of Las Vegas had ballooned to residents, portent of things to come for next years

Today Hong Kong remains capitalist enclave with its laws and rights intact, and China has promised that Hong Kong will continue in this fashion for at least years
Beijing's announced policy of maintaining Hong Kong's prosperity and stability makes sense
Hong Kong has long been China's handiest window on West, and city is unrivaled in its commercial knowhow and managerial expertise
The impression of visitor today will be that very little has changed
Establishments are no longer called Royal, Queen Elizabeth has vanished from coinage, and Union Jack has been replaced by flag of China and new Hong Kong flag with its bauhinia flower
But in fact, there have been changes, many of them due to economic progress, new construction, and other factors that influence cities all over world
Others are more subtle
British social customs are still evident in kind of polite service you get in hotels and in long lines of people waiting for buses at rush hour
The British population has decemberreased; today there are as many American and Australian expats as there are British
With population of nearly and total area of just over , square km square miles , housing is of Hong Kong's perennial nightmarches
Hong Kong is crowded, it has of world's greatest population densities
Hong Kong and Its People
Whole cities have been created in New Territories, although unimaginative architecture of these towns has been criticized
But it is also efficient, with of best transportation systems anywhere, and for such crowded place, quiet, you do not hear voices raised in anger, motorists sitting on their horns, or loud boomboxes
Old customs are still followed: Fate and luck are taken very seriously, and astrologers and fortunetellers do steady business
Before skyscraper can be built, feng shui see page investigation must take place to ensure that site and building will promote health, harmony, and prosperity
You'll also notice that gambling is passion, whether it be cards, mahjong, lottery, or horses
Hong Kong has major racetracks as well as intensive offtrack betting system, and on weekends ferries to Macau are crowded with people on their way to casinos
Sightseeing in Hong Kong starts at sea level with enthralling water traffic, mix of freighters, ferries, tugs, juneks, and yachts
From Victoria Peak, Hong Kong's highest point, or from skyscrapers and hotels, they are especially exciting at night when lights are on
The business and financial center and signature soaring architecture are on Hong Kong Island
Beyond, in New Territories, are mixture of highrise suburban towns, ancient sites and walled villages, country parks, and farms with ducks and fish ponds
Hong Kong's other, less developed islands, Lantau, Lamma, and Cheung Chau, provide getaways
You can also take ferry to Macau to find entirely different kind of city, unique blend of Chinese and Iberian culture
It's anyone's guess what may happen in future, but for now Hong Kong bristles with energy and ambition, and for visitor, this beautiful city with its contrasts and variety is exhilarating experience
You'll find Hong Kong easy to get around, people helpful, English spoken everywhere, and food that lives up to its reputation
On July, British Crown Colony of Hong Kong reverted to Chinese sovereignty as Special Administrative Region of People's Republic of China

Karnes and his staff read outgoing mail to make sure no secrets slipped out
Phone calls were monitored

On May , , men arrived on troopship Cape Victory after trip from Seattle
Tinian Island had been captured from Japan, and Seabees, construction arm of Navy, had built large airfields
The th took North Field and stayed in relative isolation from other B units on island
Karnes had his own Jeep, and went to beach and to evening movies shown by other units as often as he could
