Also, international competitors drew on large supply of very cheap labor
Jobs were scarce in other steelexporting countries, and labor laws were either nonexistent or allowed employers to pay much less for work
On worldwide scale, newer materials such as aluminum, plastic, and composites were beginning to substitute steel both at home and abroad
Steel demand worldwide was beginning to decemberline, and it affected both domestic and foreign companies
However, to American companies already suffering financial setbacks, outdated machinery, and fierce competition, this lack of demand was inconvenience they could not afford
Since this problem was national rather than local one, problems that were occurring in Youngstown were not unique
Youngstown was perhaps hit harder than any other town by collapse of steel industry, but it was not alone
The problem was national one, involving many more mills and issues than Youngstown's alone
You just can not solve nationwide problem in single city
The decemberline of world steel marchket affected not just Youngstown but entire steel community in America
Trying to prop up city's mills was impossible when faced with depression that spread throughout entire industry
The Save Our Valley Campaign: Lack of Funds and Plans
Eventually, some religious leaders involved in Ecumenical Coalition joined forces within community members and former steel mill employees to create Save Our Valley Campaign
As name suggests, local leaders wanted to instill people of Youngstown with fierce sense of urgency, driving them forward to confront steel companies and owners and help secure future of region
The events that would follow this date known as Black Monday are seen by people who witnessed them either as stories of great courage and determination or as monuments to human failure and false hope
Marches, speeches, and letter writing were all employed to help stimulate Campaign and rally people
But Campaign was bogged down heavily by lack of proper funding
People outside of area had no personal investment in mills, and so it was difficult to convince anyone from out of county to contribute funds
The lack of money proved to be crippling, because it prevented organizations involved from purchasing mills to run collectively
Without funds, Save Our Valley Campaign could do nothing major to help salvage city's dying economy
The Save Our Valley Campaign also lacked essential component: actual concrete plan
No seemed to know just how to go about fixing problems

People clung to vague ideas of worker collectivization, but no could really fathom exactly how that would work; people of Youngstown were, after all, not particularly familiar with socialism or collectivization in general
Without funds to drive efforts, or even real plan of action, Save Our Valley Campaign did more harm than good
In effect, it raised hopes of workers without having any real chance at saving anything
People became excited and waited for mills to reappear, but they never did
United Steel Workers of America was union representing Youngstown steel workers when closings hit
Initially many assumed that their union would take lead role in fighting for recovery of their jobs
However, it soon became clear that although local union leaders were prepared to fight, international branch was not

The higher levels of union became increasingly disassociated with Youngstown and its plight, attempting to shut out appeals from workers and local union representatives and to ignore what was really happening
No had ever seen shutdown of this magnitude and rapidity before, and none of leaders of USWA, not even president Lynn Williams, knew what could be done
It was clear to everyone that economic fallout from this series of closings would be of worst in US history, and so without any real precedents union leaders were flustered
Besides incompetence, USWA had other major reason for rejecting their local counterpart: fear of socialism

Obviously union itself was not afraid of socialist action, but they worried that federal government might see efforts of Youngstown workers to collectivize as movement towards socialism and perhaps even communism

If USWA supported efforts to revive mills and encouraged worker control and ownership of factories, then government and potentially other important people and institutions as well might begin to think that UWSA leaders were encouraging socialism
Regionalism
From its very first days Mahoning Valley has been area packed with small villages and hamlets
Youngstown is name of major city area, but surrounding it on all sides are small communities which to casual viewer are indistinguishable from main city itself

Petitions, protests, rallies, collectivization, and even takeover of steel company's headquarters were all attempted in desperate movement by those in industry to preserve only source of employment that this town had
Boardman, Poland Township, Struthers, Lowellville, Warren, Lordstown, Canfield, Niles, and many other towns and districts are crowded around Youngstown see Figure
People from each town work, shop, eat, and socialize in towns septemberarate from their own, making each town strongly dependent on every other town
However, although traffic is heavy between each septemberarate district, each area has its own distinct cultural ethnicity, educational system, heritage, history, and even food
For example, Struthers is poor town with large Slovak population, where education is generally better than in surrounding towns, but unemployment is much higher and pollution is widespread
Most people in Struthers are either Orthodox or Baptist
blocks over finds Boardman, welloff township with reputation for rich but unsuccessful schools
Its residents are mainly Italian and Roman Catholic, with small concentration of Methodists on east side
With many more cultures, religions, and economic levels living in close proximity to another, curious phenomenon has overtaken area: regionalism
Each town, with their own identity, instills strong regionalistic feeling within their respective populations, which dictates many habits, exchanges, and interactions between populations
Oftentimes this regionalism takes form of bizarre forms of hatred, with certain towns becoming sworn enemies of others
With so much regional tension, it became very hard for workers to unite under common cause, even that would save their jobs and their futures

Workers from Poland Township would refuse to attend rallies with workers from Campbell, and citizens of Struthers would become suspicious of people from Boardman, even if they were supposed to be working towards same thing
A lack of cooperation became crippling problem for movement, because no was willing to put aside regional differences to work together

In some instances, small companies would express interest in helping movement or in relocating their business in area, but because of regional pride no could ever agree where new businesses should relocate
In this way people of Mahoning Valley missed many opportunities for new industrial or commercial lifebruarylood because of arbitrary arguments where goal was simply to protect regional pride
These wellintentioned efforts ultimately failed, leaving thousands with shattered dreams and distinct lack of trust in fellow humankind
Conclusion: The Aftershock and Significance of Black Monday
Black Monday was devastating blow to entire generation of people

The efforts to avoid catastrophe after fact were unsuccessful for main reasons: failure of international steel marchket, lack of funds and plans in initiatives such as Save Our Valley Campaign, refusal of USWA to support their local chapter out of ineptitude and fear, and absurd but very real regionalism which corrupted solidarity efforts and drove away any hope for brining in new companies
What happened in Youngstown may not seem significant on international or even on national level, and perhaps it is not
But to thousands of people living there, loss of mills was devastating event that sent shock waves through their economic, political, and social futures
Because of mills and their conspicuous absence, hundreds of people were uprooted, forced to leave their homes and tightly knit communities
Hundreds more joined unemployment lines, or even began living on streets
The steel workers who tried to save their jobs and their lives were part of something greater than themselves, something which would endure long after they had moved away and moved on
Even though they eventually failed, fact that they tried to preserve what they felt belonged to them is amazing example of how far people will go to save their lives and futures of their children
But why did brave attempts by union leaders and concerned citizens to revive steel industry ultimately fail?

When examining area's history, culture, and economic situation we can identify main reasons: refusal of international leadership of United Steelworkers of America to support their union's Youngstown branch, lagging international steel marchket, lack of clear, organized vision for individual initiatives such as Save Our Valley Campaign, and crippling regionalism which caused animosity between different small towns in region, all contributed in some way to failure of workers and union leaders to save industry
Most importantly, problem in Youngstown was nationwide problem
A Brief History of Steel in Northeastern Ohio
In James and Daniel Heaton discovered ore and coal lining Yellow Creek in area outside of Youngstown known as Poland Township
Their blast furnace, Hopewell, was very first blast furnace in area
During Civil War, Youngstown played vital role in supplying Union army with iron products
The Decline of Northeastern Ohio Steel Market: Why Did Attempts by Union Leaders and Concerned Citizens to Revive Steel Industry Ultimately Fail?
Youngstown also was major railway crossroads, due to its strategic position between Cleveland, Pittsburgh, New York, and Chicago
In fact, More rail cars passed under Center Street Bridge major bridge in Youngstown per day than any other location in country

During th century, center of iron manufacturing had gradually shifted from far East Coast Massachusetts and Eastern Pennsylvania to Ohio Valley Pittsburgh regions of Northeast, including Mahoning Valley and Hanging Rock region of Ohio and Kentucky
By , Youngstown's population had grown to nearly , , which meant it had doubled in size over period
The town continued to prosper, driven by flux of immigrants pouring in with hopes of employment at mills
This prosperity continued until late s, when Great Depression hit area hard
Despite Congress of Industrial Organization's successful efforts to establish national steel workers' union, industry barely survived Depression years
Finally, outbreak of Second World War made iron and steel important again, and Youngstown was bolstered out of its economic standstill into fastpaced period of booming growth
Strikes racked town during forties, fifties, and sixties, and they were often long and bloody
This prohibited strikes and lockout, angering workers and driving productivity and laborer morale down

At same time, stricter governmental standards for environmental protection and growth of imported steel were making it harder to produce and marchket American steel parts, and overeager shareholders in companies' stock were pushing for more and more of their share of pie
Most importantly, Youngstown's steel mills were slowly becoming less efficient and more expensive
September , is date that few people in Youngstown, Ohio will ever forget
Black Monday and Crash of Steel Industry
Between and , total of mills were closed and approximately , jobs were lost countywide
Meetings of union officials and mill bosses were hurriedly set up in attempt to persuade powers that be to reconsider their statement
However, it was clear that, in words of USWA president Lloyd McBride, If you can not make buck, you get out of business
On that date Jennings Lambeth, president of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, announced that most of steel company's Campbell Works would close
If you can not make buck, you get out of business
The closings meant end of Youngstown's only real industry, end of its population growth, and then end of economic progress
Without mills, people sought other places of employment in adjoining states or even other areas of country
Those that could afford to move did so; those that could not afford to move mostly ended up on streets
Without industrial or residential base, commerce shrank considerably
It was becoming increasingly clear that without industrial base provided by mills, city of Youngstown would soon become ghost town, inhabited by those too poor or hopeful to escape
The workers decemberided they needed to do something to save their city, and so they mobilized in variety of ways
Attempts to Save Mills
The very first thing that workers could do was to get up petition to stop shutdown, says Ed Mann, local union leader and organizer
The International chapter of USWA had much more lobbying power, but they refused to support local union members
The petition was lost among paperwork and bureaucratic procedure
Next, workers decemberided to form Ecumenical Coalition, organization of local religious groups which spearheaded attempt to reopen Youngstown works
Although for other cities this would simply be minor economic setback, for people of Youngstown and surrounding area, it meant disaster
Lykes ignored letters, so Coalition turned once again to federal government
Here, too, they were ignored
The Coalition had no proper funds to buy mills, so they could do nothing but sit back and watch as mills closed
Finally, following shutdown of US Steel's plant in , local union leaders congregated outside US Steel Headquarters in Youngstown
They invited local people and politicians to witness scene, then charged Headquarters and took it over
The workers stayed there until next day, when US Steel decemberlared that they were ready to talk about selling mill
Immediately after workers left building, US steel representatives told local union leaders that they had changed their minds and were no longer interested in allowing workers to purchase mill
All these efforts eventually came to nothing, and Youngstown's steel mills remained closed
In fact, American steel imports were beginning to outweigh exports
Wage hikes, although they helped to improve living conditions of steel workers in US, made American steel far more expensive

It started in , when Andrew would ride around town pulling bikes out of dumpsters
He started hosting work parties with friends in his backyard, teaching them to fix their bikes and helping them get started riding
Slowly but surely, circle grew and Andrew's backyard parties became weekly workshops
When Andrew decemberided to leave town for few years' schooling in NYC, friends and cohorts took over operations
These days it is established club, run by volunteers and donations, turning trashed bikes into treasures

Its influence now includes legitimate downtown storefront; sister shop in Albany Albany Bicycle Coalition ; movie screenings and procycling political events; and dedicated core crew that keeps everything rolling
TBR's customers run gamut, from businessmen to street kids to college students to families
This group understands value of bicycle: more than just transportation, bike is statement against fossil fuels
More than toy, it is equalizer that allows poor kids to ride with rich
More than hobby, it is way of traveling through world that lets you interact, use your muscles, breathe fresh air all for cost of free dumpster bike
Remember when you got your first bike?
When I visited TBR shop, it was packed with frames, wheels, gears, chains, handlebars, kids, and anarchist art space is being donated by some supporters who are also anticapitalist activists
TBR hosts workshops twice week
Tools are available, and volunteers will help with advice and knowledge
Was it Christmas present, or maybe birthday gift?
Parts can be had for pittance, and you can pick out your own bike from stacks and racks of machines filling space
The main focus of TBR, however, is not selling bikes
The idea is to give people workspace and teach them how to maintain their own bicycle
All around me, college students and bike punks tinkered with their machines
An older man asked for tips on tuning his racer
A young kid came in to say his last bike was stolen and he needed new and, despite Andrew's stern reprimand that he could not just walk in every week and leave with free bike, he did just that
A dad came in with his kids, all of whom left with snazzy rides but first, they all sat down and worked on their new wheels together
I love what you do,
I have whole bunch of bikes to give you
See, ultimately TBR is about more than just bicycles
It's about building community, and triggering quiet but inexorable social movement
This is not world's first bike collective; in fact it is only of many that have stealthily sprung up around America
Save World, Ride Bike visit to Troy Bike Rescue
These collectives are not waiting for change to happen: they are creating it through small, positive, peaceful actions
You too can change world: all you have to do is ride bike
Fall is here, which in most places means great riding weather
What are you waiting for?
So pick up, and ride it to end of your block!
Then keep going!
Even if your life requires wheels, you can use bike for local errands
Ride it to corner store when you need milk, instead of driving across town to grocery store
Do n't like milk they sell?
Tell store owner what you like, and see if he will carry it
Now you are changing world
On weekends, instead of driving to park, hop on your bike and go exploring
Or, if you are gym buff, trade workout for bike ride
Unless you live on major highway, odds are you can ride straight from your front porch to someplace interesting
It's cheaper, and much better for local flora fauna
Then think of it this way: by riding your bike instead of driving your car, you are reducing your consumption of fossil fuels
You can even calculate money you save on gas, and keep it in jar for rainy day
Cycling is thing of past: sport, hobby, but rarely mode of transportation
Want to get involved?

David's dedicated and inspired agrarian, whose passion for farming keeps him optimistic
But farming on Outer Cape is sort of Sisyphian challenge that can wear anybody out

David points out patch of sand with thin strip of fertile loam along edge

The Outer Cape is really just spit of sand but still, farmers lived here for generations
How?
Salt marchsh hay
salt marchsh haying
Salt marchsh hay has no weed seeds, and it does not compact as heavily as other types of hay
This makes it excellent and bountiful source of compost, and it was used for generations as soil enricher
But haying had to happen regularly, says David: There's so much oxygen in this soil, any added compost gets burned up in weeks
There's so much oxygen in this soil, any added compost gets burned up in weeks All nutrients get depleted
All nutrients get depleted
The only way to keep things going here is to keep steady flow of compost coming in

While it is no longer bargain shopping destination it once was, there are still some good buys to be had
Musical, Audio, and Video Equipment
Hong Kong has vast range of most hightech audiovisual, sound, and screen equipment
Be sure to look around and compare before buying
Whatever you buy, you may be able to work out discount
Readytowear Clothes
There are still great many factory outlet stores with reasonable prices
You'll also find bargain clothes for sale at marchkets and on pushcarts
Tailormade clothes are not as popular in Hong Kong as they were in past, but hundreds of shops still remain
In choosing tailor, look for HKTA membership
Stores do not open until am or later, but shopping goes on into evening, up to : pm
Many tailors have Web sites or are listed on Web sites
Tea
Shops all over town will sell you gift tins of exotic blends
If you want to learn something about tea, go to Tea Shop at Hollywood Road, or Moon Garden Tea House at Hoi Ping Road, Causeway Bay
The owners will brew up pot so you can taste before making choice
Watches
Be sure to get manufacturer's guarantee stamped or signed if you buy watch
Entertainment
Most shops are open days week
Hong Kong Diary published weekly by HKTA tells what is happening in arts
Hong Kong Life is published by Hong Kong Standard on Sunday, and South China Morning Post has entertainment section on Friday
Culture buffs are well catered to, and there is always varied program of events, ranging from worldclass concerts to local amateur dramatic productions

A highlight of arts calendar is annual Hong Kong Arts Festival, dose of international culture in February, with concerts, recitals, plays, jazz, Chinese opera, and innovemberative productions put on by leading talent from both East and West
Tickets for shows must be reserved well in advance
The Festival of Asian Arts takes place every other October, bringing to Hong Kong for weeks orchestras, dance groups, opera, and drama companies from all over Asia
There are more than cinemas in Hong Kong, and latest Western releases are shown in some of larger ones
Englishlanguage films have Chinese subtitles
The Hong Kong International Film Festival takes place in April
More than films from all over world are shown at this event
Ask at City Hall center about advance reservations
The Performing Arts
Performance Venues
The theaters in Hong Kong Cultural Center in Tsim Sha Tsui are main venues for concerts and opera

Other performance centers are City Hall cultural complex, with exhibition halls and theaters that present concerts, plays, and films; Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts with major theaters for dance, drama, and concert performances; and Hong Kong Arts Centre in Wan Chai, where both local and visiting groups perform
Larger arenas, including Queen Elizabeth Stadium, Hong Kong Coliseum, and Ko Shan Theater in Kowloon play host to various concerts, pop concerts, sporting events, and variety shows
The Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra performs new and traditional works; wide assortment of traditional and Chinese instruments are featured
Buyer Beware
The Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra was founded in
Under its conductor, David Atherton, it offers Western classical works and new works by Chinese composers in SeptembertoJune season
Be aware that name brands, including electronics, are sometimes fakes, glass may be sold as jade, and that antique you bought may have been made last night
Chinese Opera
To most foreigners, this unique art form is likely to be inscrutable at first exposure, but everyone can appreciate spectacle and elaborate, glittering costumes
Although music may seem strange to unaccustomed ear, it certainly will not put you to sleep; cymbals and drums guarantee your alertness

Hong Kong's professional dance companies, Hong Kong Ballet Company, Hong Kong Dance Company, and newer City Contemporary Dance Company, perform regularly, often at Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts

The leading local troupes, Chung Ying Theatre Company and Hong Kong Repertory Theatre, perform in Cantonese; there are Englishlanguage performances at Fringe Club theaters, Lower Albert Road, in Central
Puppet Shows
The classic Chinese puppet is shadow puppet, manipulated behind screen by rods, but hand puppet and marchionette shows are also on offer, often for free at public parks and playgrounds
Nightlife
Hong Kong by night can suit any taste, riotous, sedate, raw, or cultured
Note that sometimes there is cover charge of HK to HK at clubs, which may or may not include couple of drinks
There are nightclubs in principal hotels, with bands, dancing, and floor shows
Always ask for receipt that records information about item, and if you buy antique, be sure to get certificate of authentication
Jazz fans will find live jazz presented by international artists at Jazz Club and Bar, F, D'Agular, Central; and at Blue Note in Kowloon ShangriLa Hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui
The Frin ge Club, Lower Albert Road, Central, is Hong Kong's bestknown alternate entertainment venue, with jazz, rock, and other live music, in addition to gallery for visual arts
Bars with views and live music include Sky Lounge in Sheraton Hotel and Towers, Tsim Sha Tsui; and Cyrano in Island ShangriLa in Pacific Place
In Tsim Sha Tsui, Ned Kelly's Last Stand on Ashley Road is Aussie institution; Delaney's, Peking Road, is of Hong Kong's enduring Irish pubs
Joe Bananas, Luard Road, is Wan Chai mainstay for allnight partying
A lot of raunchy action has moved across harbor to Tsim Sha Tsui East; this is also where you will find pricey hostess clubs, popular with Japanese tourists, but definitely not for those on budget
Today's trendy spot is Soho SOuth of HOllywood around Hollywood Road, Elgin, and Stauton streets
Needless to say, avoid peddlers who approach you on street and offer to take you to wondrous bargains
TOTT's, in Excelsior Hotel, is restaurant with live music and dancing and harbor view
Japanese karaoke bars have now become extremely popular with locals
There are number of these on Chatham Road South and around Cameron Street in Tsim Sha Tsui
The most typical of these are harbor cruises, usually including dinner and dancing on board airconditioned floating nightclub
There are evening bus tours that include visits to restaurant and night spots; some tours combine Chinese banquet with visit to openair marchket and panorama from Victoria Peak
In subtropical Hong Kong you can swim from April to early November
There are more than beaches in Hong Kong that are free to public
Most have lifeguards on duty from April to October, changing rooms, toilets, and snack stands
On Hong Kong Island, Repulse Bay is most popular; others are Shek O on east coast and Stanley and Deep Water Bay on south coast
They are very crowded, especially on summer weekends
The large department stores have fixed prices, but elsewhere you should ask whether there is discount, especially if you buy several items in shop
On outlying islands, Cheung Chau and Cheung Sha are on Lantau, and Hung Shing Ye and Lo So Shing on Lamma; inquire about water pollution levels
The Hong Kong Golf Club Tel welcomes visitors to its hole courses at Fanling in New Territories, or hole course at Deep Water Bay
The par course was designed by Dave Thomas
Hiking
In New Territories famous MacLehose Trail stretches km miles from Sai Kung Peninsula to Tuen Mun
The Lantau Trail is km mile circular trail on Lantau Island that begins and ends at Silvermine Bay
Both trails are divided into smaller segments of varying difficulty
Maps of hiking trails are available at Government Publications Center, Low Block, Government Offices, Queensway in Central
HKTA also has trail maps and sponsors Guided Nature Walks, led by rangers, that include hikes in all different regions of Hong Kong
Jogging
Victoria Park has jogging track in Causeway Bay
Sailing
Contact Hong Kong Yacht Club at Tel for information
Compare prices before you buy any significant item
Taijiquan Tai Chi
HKTA offers lessons in these exercises that improve concentration and balance at Garden Plaza, Hong Kong Park, Admiralty Tel
Tennis
There are public courts at Victoria Park Tennis Centre Tel
Horseracing
All levels of society share feverish interest in Sport of Kings
The racing schedule is September to June, and Hong Kong maintains tracks, older Happy Valley course on Hong Kong Island and striking Sha Tin track in New Territories
Always ask to see manufacturer's guarantee when purchasing watches, cameras, and audiovisual and electronic equipment
The Hong Kong Tourist Association runs Come Horseracing Tour, which includes entry to Hong Kong Jockey Club visitors' box and members' enclosure, and buffetstyle meal
Cricket
Since Hong Kong is dutyfree port and charges no sales tax, goods are cheaper here than in country where they were made
Hong Kong has many attractions that appeal to children of all ages
Hong Kong's many beaches are especially fun for children
Children love riding on Hong Kong's antique trams
A ride on Peak Tram is sure to provide thrill, and in Peak Tower they will enjoy Peak Explorer ride and Ripley's Believe it or Not! Ocean Park see page is popular with children of all ages
There's special Kid's World that those under can enter free when accompanied by paying adult

The Science Museum in Tsim Sha Tsui East allows children to get their hands on over half of its exhibits, while nearby Space Museum has regular screenings on enormous Omnimax screen in its Space Theater, making night sky come vibrantly alive
Note that when haggling, merchant assumes you are prepared to pay cash
For children who love boats, riding Star Ferry or ferry trips to outlying islands will be exciting, and Dolphin Watch trip see page is certain to appeal
If you plan to visit during May, carnival atmosphere of Cheung Chau Bun Festival, with its high bambooandpaper towers covered in sticky buns, will fascinate young ones
If, after concluding deal, you try to pay with credit card, he may then boost price in order to cover card charges
It is advisable to shop at outlets that are members of Hong Kong Tourist Association HKTA , identified by red junek logo

Membership imposes obligation to maintain standards of both quality and service, and provides dissatisfied customers with officially recognized channel for redressing complaints; number to call is Tel
Pick up copy of HKTA's The Official Dining, Entertainment Shopping Directory in which all member stores are listed
Shipping
Ask if automatic free insurance is provided
If goods are very valuable or fragile, it is good idea to buy allrisk insurance for shipment
Packages sent to US or to Europe generally take to weeks by surface mail, and week by airmail
Shopping Areas

Major shopping areas are Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon, especially along Nathan Road; Central on Hong Kong Island, particularly for upscale designer goods; Causeway Bay for slightly better prices; and Hollywood Road area
On photographic equipment, electronic goods, and watches, you avoid luxury tax payable in your home country
Department Stores

Look for Lane Crawford Ltd, upscale store with branches at Pacific Place, Queen's Road, and Harbour City; Wing On, of oldest in Hong Kong; Marks and Spencer; and Japanese department stores, Mitsukoshi, Sobo, and Seibu
Malls
Hong Kong is full of giant malls

Harbour City, just west of Star Ferry Terminal in Tsim Sha Tsui is of largest; Pacific Place, Queensway, is Central's biggest mall, with retail outlets and department stores; Times Square is collection of retail outlets in Causeway Bay
These stores sell excess stock or factory overruns
Hong Kong is no longer factory outlet center since much of its clothing manufacturing has moved elsewhere
There are factory showrooms in Pedder Building, Pedder Street, in Central
Markets
Markets are places to use your bargaining skills
Hong Kong's most famous and colorful marchket is Temple Street Night Market near Jordan MTR stop
Every conceivable kind of goods is sold here: clothing, all kinds of electronics, CDs, souvenirs, crafts, and jewelry
Stanley Market is located on Hong Kong's southern coast, and is wellknown for all kinds of clothing, including silk and cashmere
Bargain, and carefully examine any merchandise you buy here
The Jade Market, on Kansu Street in Yau Ma Tei, is known for both jade and freshwater pearls
This is not place to make expensive purchases, but it is great for inexpensive pendants, earrings, and gifts
What to Buy
Antiques
Hollywood Road in MidLevels above Central is most famous antiques street in Hong Kong
Look for fine Chinese bronzes, embroidery, lacquerware and porcelain, tomb figures, and wood carvings, among other possibilities
The experts out that it is not age alone that determines Chinese antique's value, dynasties of past had their creative ups and downs
Custommade garments by skillful Hong Kong tailors are still much in demand and cost less than elsewhere for comparable garments
For serious antiques, try Honeychurch Antiques at no for furniture and silver, Tai Sing Company at for porcelain
For fun you can visit Low Price Shop at no or Cat Street crafts stores and flea marchket
Inflation has taken its toll in Hong Kong
Brocades and Silks
Fabrics from China are bargain and well worth taking home
Photo buffs know that Hong Kong is place to buy some of world's most advanced photographic equipment, and there are some real bargains around
However, be sure you compare prices and models before buying
reliable places to start looking in Lan Kwai Fong are Photo Scientific in Eurasia Building and Hing Lee Camera Company, Lyndhurst Terrace
Carpets and Rugs
Hong Kong is mecca for Chinese handknotted wool carpets and silk rugs
Hong Kong's stores are usually able to arrange shipment
Caravan at Hollywood Road and shops in The Silk Road at Ocean Center in Tsim Sha Tsui are good places to start looking
Note that alcohol and tobacco are both exceptions to Hong Kong's dutyfree regime and are subject to tax
China Porcelain
In Hong Kong you can have plate, or even whole dinner service, handpainted to your own design
Factories in Kowloon and New Territories, producing traditional and modern china, are geared to entertain and instruct visiting tourists; prices are appealing

of largest places to go are Wah Tung China Company in Grand Marine Industrial Building in Aberdeen; and Overjoy Porcelain Factory in Block B of Kwai Hing Industrial Building, Kwai Chung, in New Territories
In antiques shops, look for highly valued porcelains from China
Note that because of dutyfree situation, good bargains may be found in European china, including Spode and Wedgwood
Electronics
The latest gadgets are sometimes available in Hong Kong before anywhere else
Before you begin shopping, pick up HKTA's Shopping Guide to Consumer Electronics
Prices on electronics have risen in past years; check prices at home before you buy here
Nathan Road has many electronics shops
You'll find that prices are about same in Hong Kong Central and Kowloon, and somewhat cheaper in Causeway Bay, which caters to local shopping
Furniture
Hollywood Road has several furniture shops
Queen's Road East in Wan Chai is furniture manufacturing and retail area
Jade
Good for health is just of many magical qualities that are attributed to these beautiful emeraldgreen or turquoise stones
Real jade is extremely expensive, and you may be offered counterfeit jade, which looks exactly like genuine article
Some people say you can test authenticity by touch, real jade feels smooth and cool
Alternatively, you can shine lamp on stone, real jade shows no reflected light
Better still, go shopping with expert
Jewelry
Thanks to dutyfree situation, prices in Hong Kong are lower than they are in some other places
Popular purchases include diamonds and freshwater pearls
The statues in main shrine represent Man, god of literature, and Mo, god of war, curious juxtaposition
The temple is always crowded with worshipers
Just past temple is aptly named Ladder Street
As you get off, story Jardine House with portholeshaped windows catches eye
Go down flight of steps to Lascar Row, popularly known as Cat Street, for more antiques and curio shops
Walk up steps to reach Caine Lane, where you will find Museum of Medical Sciences open Tuesday Saturday am pm; admission by donation
The interesting Edwardian building was formerly Pathological Institute, founded to combat th century's yearlong outbreak of bubonic plague
Servicemen relaxing from rigors of Vietnam War poured millions of dollars into Wan Chai boom of s
There are restaurants and Starbuck's in basement, and you can access raised pedestrian crosswalk from escalators on ground floor
The Wan Chai waterfront is dominated by Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre, largest in Asia, which includes hotels, theaters, and exhibition halls
The convention center, extension on reclaimed land, affords stunning views of Wan Chai waterfront
Adjacent, just west of convention center, is another modern highlight, Academy for Performing Arts on Gloucester Road
On Wan Chai's Bowen Road, Maiden's Rock, also called Lover's Rock, is gathering place for annual Maiden's festival
Although it is not tourist attraction, rock is steeped in tradition
Every August young women convene to light joss sticks and some even climb ft rock to pray for good husbands
A prosperous tourist district, it is full of shopping centers and department stores, along with number of good restaurants
The busy nightandday crowds make this area vibrant and lively
On nautical side is Causeway Bay typhoon shelter, where expensive yachts are anchored almost gunwale to gunwale, and Hong Kong Yacht Club has its headquarters
Across Gloucester Road, opposite World Trade Centre, is Noonday Gun, which under British rule was sounded on stroke of midday
Next to Jardine building is Exchange Square, complex with large shopping mall; just behind it is General Post Office with philatelic center on ground floor
It's not clear how custom started
story has it that traders Jardine, Matheson Co fired private salute for visiting tycoon, act that incensed colonial authorities, who felt that they had sole right to issue such gun welcome
As result, merchants were forced to limit their salvoes to day, and from then on, they signaled noon hour daily for all to hear
The gun was made famous by Noel Coward's satirical song, Mad Dogs and Englishmen
Farther east is Hong Kong's largest park, Victoria Park, with sports grounds and other facilities
On eastern side of Victoria Park on Causeway Road is Tin Hau Temple, dedicated to Tin Hau, Taoist Queen of Heaven and patroness of seafarers
On rd day of Third Moon, birthday of goddess is celebrated here and in all Hong Kong fishing communities
Inland from bay is Happy Valley
At time it was very miserable valley, swampland conducive only to breeding malarial mosquitoes
It is home to Hong Kong's first racetrack
Hong Kong's gamblers are so eager to play horses that, despite opening of bigger and better racetrack at Sha Tin, Happy Valley Racecourse is thriving
Up Tai Hang Road behind Causeway Bay is Aw Boon Haw Tiger Balm Gardens open daily : am pm , founded in by late Aw Boon Haw, who became millionaire by producing medicinal Tiger Balm
It does not, in fact, contain any ingredients from tigers, but does promise to cure wide range of problems such as colds, headaches, rheumatism, gout, toothache, and scorpion bites
Farther west is ferry terminal for outlying islands

Aberdeen, island's oldest settlement, once pirate lair, is home to floating population , boat people who spend their entire lives on juneks in harbor, some proudly claiming never to have set foot on land except for funerals, which do not count

The juneks are picturesque sight: children frolicking on poop decemberk, women preparing food or playing mahjong, elderly folk watching sunset, dogs and cats underfoot, songbirds in bamboo cages overhead, and all afloat
On Connaugustht Road Central, you will find of Hong Kong's curiosities, m ft long MidLevels outdoor escalator
The boats may appear decembereptively primitive, but many of them have their own electric generators and all modern conveniences
There are fewer boats now than in past; many boat people, especially younger generation, have moved to housing projects
You can take tour of port in of small sampans, propelled by hand by women drivers
A halfhour tour costs HK ; pay at end, or driver may cut your trip short
The peninsula opposite east coast of Ap Lei Chau island contains Ocean Park open daily am pm; admission HK adults, HK children , which has become of Hong Kong's biggest attractions
It is divided into areas: highland, lowland, and Middle Kingdom
Linking lowland and highland sections of park, cablecar system offers spectacular views across to islands of South China Sea
It ferries commuters from MidLevels apartment complexes downhill from to am, and uphill from am to midnight
The Oceanarium is said to be largest in world, and Ocean Theatre features displays by dolphins, killer whales, seals, and pelicans
An enormous rollercoaster rising way above sea, space wheels, and highdiving shows guarantee day of excitement
The Middle Kingdom is recreated living history of China's past, presented through number of fullsize replicas of shrines, temples, pagodas, palaces, and street scenes
There are also demonstrations of traditional Chinese crafts, including silkweaving, pottery, and p apermaking
Water World, formerly in complex, has closed for redevelopment
The next inlet is Repulse Bay, roomy, sandy crescent, with green hills
It's so attractive and so easy to reach that it is packed with sunbathers all summer long
Stanley was once of main fishing villages on Hong Kong Island
The wellknown Stanley Market see page is major source for bargain clothing and other merchandise
Stanley is also favorite place of residence for expats
Nearby is Central Market, wholesale food marchket of Hong Kong, and Hang Seng building private offices
The waterfronts at Repulse Bay and Stanley are lined with good cafs and restaurants
Though much smaller than Hong Kong Island, Kowloon has almost twice population
In many areas, density reaches equivalent of , inhabitants per square km quarter square mile
Most of Kowloon's attractions for visitors are centered near tip of peninsula in district known as Tsim Sha Tsui
Adjacent to Star Ferry terminal is Ocean Terminal, where international cruise ships dock, and gigantic Harbour City, complex of malls, hotels, and restaurants
If you walk east on Star Ferry terminal concourse, you will find yourself on wonderful Promenade, which begins at clock tower, all that remains of once grand KowloonCanton Railway Terminus
The waterfront here offers unparalled views of harbor and Hong Kong Island
Flanked by clock tower is imposing Hong Kong Cultural Centre
Hong Kong's major venue for performing arts, building has been criticized for its fortresslike architecture and windowless faade
The interior is comfortable amalgam of Chinese and Western design, with impressive main lobby
The center contains concert hall with acclaimed acoustics, theaters, library, exhibition gallery, shops, restaurants, and bars
Next door is Hong Kong Space Museum and Theatre open Monday, Wednesday Friday pm; Saturday, Sunday am pm; closed Tuesday; admission HK adults, HK children; septemberarate admission to theater
Its futuristic dome design is striking; inside are interactive exhibits, including in which you can experience weightlessness
No longer center of government, it now functions as cultural center
The theater presents sky shows and IMAX films
The Hong Kong Museum of Art see page stands behind Space Museum next to cultural center
Particularly interesting is collection of paintings and photographs of old Hong Kong
The museum mounts special exhibitions and has excellent gift shop
A few blocks up Chatham Road South are more major museums
The Science Museum see page is stateoftheart interactive museum that will teach you how everything and anything works from ancient sailing ships to latest technology
The fascinating collection of artifacts pertaining showcases , years of Hong Kong's history and Chinese culture
Its restored lobby is Hong Kong's most elegant gathering place; afternoon tea here is visitors' ritual
Kowloon's main street was created by Sir Matthew Nathan when he was governor of Hong Kong at turn of th century
At time it was built, many thought it absurd to have treelined boulevard running through what was practically wilderness
Now former Nathan's Folly is known as Golden Mile
Farther up Nathan Street you will reach Yau Ma Tei, of older parts of Kowloon
Turn off Nathan and walk down Kansu Street to find Jade Market open am pm; see page , with more than stalls spread out in large tent, just before you reach overpass
Hong Kong's liveliest marchket scene is Temple Street Night Market see page , near Jordan Road
Everything is sold here, from clothing to souvenirs to electronic goods, and marchket is known for its streetside food stalls, where you can dine inexpensively on seafood
So great is pressure on available land that most of Hong Kong's colonial architectural heritage has been demolished and replaced by new skyscrapers
The marchket runs all way up to Tin Hau Temple, where you will find fortune tellers' tables some speak English and possibly street performers singing Chinese opera or pop songs
The temple is of many dedicated to Tin Hau, goddess of seafarers; this also houses altar to Shing Wong, city's god
In daytime temple open am pm attracts worshipers, and its park attracts strollers and mahjong players
Nathan Road goes all way up to Boundary Street, which marchks boundary between Kowloon and New Territories
Near Boundary Street, off Prince Edward Street West, is Yuen Po Street Bird Garden open am pm
Birds are favorite pets in Hong Kong, valued for their singing rather than their plumage, and here you will find all kinds of birds for sale as well as elaborate teak and bamboo cages
This ancient burial vault is believed to date back to Han Dynasty d
The barrelvaulted chambers were discovered while excavating for nearby housing project

Surprises spring up on all sides: new industrial complexes alongside sleepy farming villages, skyscraper towns blooming in middle of nowhere, Hakka women in their traditional flat straw hats with hanging black curtains, water buffalo, and flashes of azalea everywhere
The New Territories can be explored by taking Kowloon Canton Railway KCR , which makes stops between station in Kowloon and Sheung Shui, last stop before entering China
Ask tourist authority about its interesting Heritage Tour from Kowloon and other countryside tours see page
The main highway makes circuit of New Territories, beginning with new town of Tsuen Wan, situated in area of heavy industry just west of Kowloon
Nearby is Chater Garden and number of notable architectural landmarchks
The highway continues parallel to coast
Thus you will find mile Beach at Castle Peak Bay
The main road continues clockwise around New Territories

Most famous is striking story I M Pei Bank of China Tower, not beloved by people of Hong Kong, its triangular prisms and sharp angles violate principles of feng shui see box, page and its radio masts stick up like insect's antennae
Set amid Tseun Wan's residential towers is thcentury walled village of Sam Tung Uk, now preserved as museum, and short walk from MTR station
Not far away, at milepost near large new town of Tuen Mun, is Taoist retreat known as Ching Chung Koon
This Temple of Green Pines is spacious complex containing temples and pavilions, statues, and gardens
It is known for its collection of bonsai and houses jade seal more than , years old
This is most easily accessible of New Territories' walled villages
It is built in square, and only way in is through gate in brick defensive wall
Kat Hing Wai was built or centuries ago by Hakka Tang clan, of Great Clans that migrated here from North China see page
Many of old houses in village have been replaced by modern structures
Few traditional ancestral halls remain in China since antihistorical destruction during Cultural Revolution, so these New Territories ancestral halls are rare survivors
of most interesting sites in New Territories is Tai Fu Tai, another rare survivor, this mansion that belonged to Confucian high official
The house was built in by member of Man clan who achieved rank of tai fu mandarin by doing well in Imperial Examinations
The preservation of this wonderful home is ongoing; projected restoration of original garden is still in progress
The highway and railway stay close together from Fanling, site of best golf courses in area
Just up lane from marchket is Man Mo Temple, with longburning incense coils hanging from its ceiling, popular spot dedicated to Taoist gods of war and literature
The railway line then curves gracefully around Tolo Harbor, idyllic body of water wellprotected from open sea
You can take ferryboat through harbor, past ingenious Plover Cove reservoir, water catchment area appropriated by damming and draining broad inlet from sea
The boats go on to friendly fishermen's island of Tap Mun, in Mirs Bay, with stops in remote hamlets of Sai Kung Peninsula
From next railway station, modern campus of Chinese University of Hong Kong is visible
Teaching here is conducted in both Chinese and English
Sha Tin is site of Monastery of , Buddhas, which looks down on burgeoning town
There are hundreds of stone steps in hillside to walk up before you reach Man Fat Temple with its regiments of small gilt statues of Buddha lining walls
Some indefatigable climbers will want to go up to top of pink pagoda for panoramic view
From inside vast atrium you can view whole structure as well as mechanical workings of building
Down to earth, Sha Tin Racecourse can accommodate over , spectators and is equipped with every imaginable luxury, including giant video screen facing stands, and for horses, airconditioned stables
Opposite Sha Tin railway station, New Town Plaza features shops, cinemas, and even computercontrolled musical fountain
natural rock formations are always pointed out on excursions
bronze lions, carrying out feng shui principles, guard its doors
It really looks part; tourists know its name even before guide can translate it
Excursion companies sell variety of orientation cruises of Hong Kong harbor that include look at some of its outlying islands
You can catch of Hong Kong's historic trams along Des Voeux Road and ride from Central to Causeway Bay see box, page
The mountainous island of Lantau is biggest in colony, and covers nearly twice area of Hong Kong Island
Chek Lap Kok airport sits on reclaimed land just off Lantau; plans to build bridge may change Lantau, but at present it is sparsely populated and makes perfect getaway
At m , ft , Lantau Peak is high enough to attract occasional rain cloud, refreshingly cool breezes blow on most hot summer days
Ferries depart from Central every hours between : am and : pm to Silvermine Bay Mui Wo , where bus terminal has buses to all parts of island
There are also ferries to Discovery Bay
A short bus ride away is Cheung Sha Beach, km miles long, and popular for its white sand and excellent facilities
The most famous site on island is world's tallest seated bronze statue of Buddha at m ft , Tiantan Buddha see page
In , narrow, doubledecemberker trams ran along waterfront, but land reclamation has placed them far inland
You can have delicious vegetarian lunch here
The hillsides that surround monastery are site of Hong Kong's only tea plantation
Visitors are welcome to visit hectare acre establishment, and may sample end product, Lantau tea
A Trappist monastery, situated on hillside overlooking east coast of Lantau, is also open to visitors
More than , people live here, mostly by fishing, but there are also expats, attracted by its laidback Mediterranean ambience
The island has checkered past of smuggling and pira cy
The people still carve jade and build seaworthy juneks, all by hand
Fish heads discreetly wrapped in paper are still hung out to dry in sun
Cheung Chau becomes center of Hong Kong life once year, usually in May, during Bun Festival, folklore extravaganza see page
The rest of year, life goes on at its accustomed pace: rickety machines chugging in factories, children in school uniforms being ferried home to houseboats, and old fishermen stirring shrimp paste
By way of formal tourist attractions, Pak Tai Temple, built in , has some fine carvings and great iron sword said to be years old
But most interesting thing to do here is to explore villages on island, Cheung Chau and San Wai
They are easy walk apart by harbor road, or longer minute hike on scenic Peak Road
The Praya, promenade in front of ferry pier, is good place to observe many juneks and fishing boats in harbor
There are also several openair restaurants where you can enjoy fresh seafood
Only minutes by ferry from Central, Lamma Island is perfect for swimming, hiking, picnicking, birdwatching, or just sitting back to watch bananas grow
Built , this usually deserted Anglican foundation is Hong Kong's oldest church
Hong Kong's third largest island has population of only about , ; it is still largely undeveloped, and life on Lamma, if not totally primitive, is close to essentials
Archaeologists indicate that Lamma has probably been inhabited for some , years, and island is known as Hong Kong's Stone Age Island
The principal settlements are Yung Shue Wan on Lamma's northwest, and Sok Kwu Wan, on east coast
Both villages offer good waterfront restaurants with homestyle Chinese food, principally seafood fresh from tank
The ports are within hiking distance of several beautiful beaches, and within hike of each other on marchked trail
You can build appetite for dinner by making your way from beach to restaurant
Yung Shue Wan is still very British residential enclave, with many nice pubs
During World War II, church was turned into club for Japanese officers; it was restored after war
Macau, final bastion of Portugal's great thcentury empire, is much more than just quirk of history
Here, where East and West first met, life combines spirit of Asia with something of sunny atmosphere of Mediterranean
No matter how many tunnels and transit systems speed crossharbor traffic, nothing matches ride on Star Ferry from Kowloon to Central District across Victoria Harbor
Macau's historic center, with its colonial architecture, has distinctly Mediterranean flavor
The story of Western discovery of Macau begins in when Portuguese explorer, Jorge Alvares, reached south coast of China
Traders followed in his wake, setting up bases in several parts of Pearl River estuary
Finally, in , they were all consolidated in Macau
It was only European gateway to China, and through Macau flowed Western technology and religion
In Pope Gregory XIII created Macau diocese, covering all of China and Japan
Note stained glass windows in Quiet Chapel, designed by Joseptemberh Edward Nuttgens in late s
No less impressive were secular challenges
The Dutch sent invasion flotilla to Macau in , but defenders triumphed
However, end of golden age was drawing near
China began to relax trade restrictions, and with rise of Hong Kong, Macau became isolated Portuguese outpost
A haven for persecuted Japanese Christians in th century, Portugal's neutrality during World War II assured territory flood of refugees
They were joined by swarm of spies of all conceivable nationalities, and Macau won name for international intrigue
Portugal's very precarious foothold on Asian coast ended in with formal handover to China
Macau, now Chinese Special Economic Zone of Zhuhai, is becoming something like boomtown as exporter of toys, furniture, and electronics
Macau's population is estimated at around , , appallingly high figure for such small area; recent land reclamation has eased situation to some extent
Gambling provides almost percent of government's tax revenues, and is major source of employment
Its spinoff industries, prostitution and pawn shops, also thrive
The easiest way to get to Macau is by jetfoil, operated by TurboJet Tel
Across from I M Pei tower winding path leads up to Hong Kong Park
The mile trip takes about hour
Departures are from Macau Ferry Terminal, just west of Central in Shun Tak Centre, Connaugustht Road, Central, in Hong Kong
Entry procedures are similar to those in Hong Kong, most nationalities need only passport to enter Macau
Upon arrival in Macau, be sure to stop by Macau Government Tourist Office for map, brochures, and directions
You'll also be approached by pedicab drivers; these are tricycles carrying passengers
Pedicabs were once most common form of transportation in Macau, but today they are mainly tourist attraction
Directly across street from wharf where passengers arrive from Hong Kong is first surprise to greet visitors to Macau, vast Jaialai Palace, said to be world's most luxurious front
In effort to provide yet more thing to bet on, players are imported from Spain to take part in this lightningfast Basque ball game
The grandstand situated on seaside road, Avenida da Amizade Friendship Avenue , marchks finishing line for Macau Grand Prix, international carracing event held here every November
Also in front of ferry terminal is new Cyber fountain, with water spouts that shoot up to m ft and are illuminated at night by spotlights producing colors
Continuing around peninsula in clockwise direction brings you to Rua da Praia Grande Big Beach Street , pleasant promenade with shaded benches under banyan trees
The central square of historic city center is Largo do Senado
The inscription over archway reads, Cidade do nome de Deus, no ha outra mais leal City of Name of God, None is More Loyal , bit of praise attributed to Portugal's King John IV in th century
In park is Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware see page
For all its historic grandeur, loyal Senate now is equivalent of city council, its statesmanship dedicated to water supplies, sewage lines, and establishment of playgrounds
Macau's most memorable monument is Baroque faade of ruins of So Paulo, only remains of beautiful thcentury Jesuit church
The rest of building and adjoining college were destroyed in typhoonfanned fire in
Beneath church, Museum of Sacred Art houses collection of sacramental objects
The ambitious Museum of Macau open Tuesday Sunday am pm; admission HK opened in in lower levels of Monte Fortress
Entrance is by escalator, near St Paul's
It gives overview of Macau's history and its daily life and traditions
A recreated street of colonial Macau is lined with traditional Chinese shops
Next to museum, behind gate opened to anyone who knocks , is Old Protestant Cemetery
Those whose fate was to die on some far foreign field could not have wanted more peaceful, lovely graveyard
The small, whitewashed chapelwas first Protestant church built in China
For different vision of Old China, spend few quiet moments in classic Lou Lim Ieoc Garden
Here, arched bridges, pagodas, fish ponds, and stands of bamboo create mood of timeless Chinese painting
Nearby is Memorial House of Dr Sun Yatsen, founder of Chinese Republic
Photos and documents tell life story of physicianrevolutionarystatesman, who lived for time in Macau, but never in this building
Kun Iam Tong, off Avenida do Coronel Mesquita open daily am pm , is thcentury Buddhist temple of considerable splendor and charm
An unexpected piece of historical memorabilia turns up in monastery garden, where guides out small stone table used for treatysigning ceremony in
The signatories, who were Chinese viceroy from Canton and minister plenipotentiary of United States of America, put their names to historic document, firstever treaty between countries
Nearby is Macau Cultural Center and Museum of Art open Tuesday Sunday am pm; closed Monday; small admission
For more than century, most exhilarating way up Victoria Peak has been by funicular
Macau's oldest museum, Maritime Museum Wednesday Monday am : pm; admission HK , HK children over traces history of Macau's connection to sea
Exhibits cover fishing, seaborne trade, sea transport, and there is aquarium
The museum also offers boat tours aboard fishing junek
The museum is almost on spot where Portuguese first landed
When they came ashore they found AMa Temple properly called Ma Kok Temple; open daily dawn to dusk , dedicated to favorite goddess of fishermen, who is also known as Tin Hau
The area was called AMa Gau Bay of AMa , and in this way, Macau got its name
The ornate, picturesque temple dates from Ming Dynasty and is oldest building in Macau
The remains of thcentury Barra Fortress, which once defended southern tip of peninsula, contains chapel of Santiago St James
The Peak Tram starts its scenic climb just across street and around corner from American Consulate in Garden Road and makes its way, sometimes at startlingly steep incline, to summit at m , ft
The saint is much revered in surrounding area
